workspaces is put together so a
workspace instance is launched in an Amazon managed VPC it is a dual honed which is say has two interfaces and
those interfaces are not bridged and they're not routed so they operate independently e0 which we call our
management interface in the documentation connects to a workspaces gateway and that is the end point to
which your workspaces client connects a connection is established over TLS
exchange occurs for authentication and a pixel stream is then returned to the
client application on the device tablet workstation or zero client the eath one
interface which we call the primary interface is extended into the customers VPC and from that ethernet interface the
customer is able to access resources that are in the VPC out through the internet gateway or back over a direct
connect or VPN into the customer network so the eath one interface you can think
of as the kind of default route for everything that occurs in the workspace environment the e0 interface is just
used for streaming PCoIP data to the end user alright so now that we understand

workspaces so when provides you the ability to curate a catalog of
applications simplify deployment administration and maintenance of those applications
you can so web applications will come from really one of three places either
the AWS marketplace for desktop apps so similar to the marketplace that we have for ec2 there is one that is now

that you've developed in-house whether they are you know batch files or CMD files or if they are compiled exe s you
can bring those and lastly the third type is third party applications where
you've already pre licensed software so if you have let's say a productivity suite you can bring that into wam for
the purpose of management and distribution amazon web applications are
delivered in what we call secure virtualized app containers so this
approach allows us to decouple the application from the operating system and the result of that is that the
management and administration of scale of both your operating system and your application are simplified so you have
the opportunity to for example rebuild a workstation if you need to or to apply
operating system patches and not worry about direct impacts on the application or overrides of files and things of that
nature these two things are operating separately one is physically on disk the operating environment and the other one
is operating in a virtualized app container and of course because of this
decoupling you're maint you don't need to maintain a series of pre-built images for each particular configuration in
your environment and instead you're maintaining a common image for your
workspace and then you're delivering applications to your users both required in optional applications through the web
service ultimately when is going to allow you to reduce your burden on the

wim also allows you to track in real time the allocation of applications

is an interesting kind of feature of wham which is oftentimes difficult to
convey so I will do my best wam offers you four levels of isolation with
respect to the virtualized app container so i'll start with layer one which is to
say that anything that is installed at layer one is physically installed on the underlying operating system and on the
file system so you can imagine installing let's say a driver for an
antivirus product or a DAT file that needs to be available at the time the system is booting so it needs to be
physically on the disk and it needs to be running before the web service and client are potentially running so one is
we put it on the disk and it stays on the disk we make no attempt to clean up any files that are placed after the user
uninstalls and layer 2 we do try to remove the files so things still go on
to the underlying OS and its file system but we make an attempt to remove those files if the system package rather the
app container is uninstalled layer 3 is our default layer at this layer of
virtualization everything runs in the context of the virtualized app container there is nothing that is actually
resident on the underlying file system and the application execution is visible
to other application that are running in the context of the workspace so normal operation would be
at layers layer three the last layer layer 4 is a very interesting one at
four you are able to completely isolate your application into the context of its virtualized app container so the reason
that I find this so interesting is many people operate websites and have web
applications and they're testing for compatibility for example with web browsers so using layer for isolation
you're able to run let's say ie seven eight nine ten in individual of
virtualized app containers they're not aware of one another which means that you don't have to deal with the all conflicts you know any of this dependent
library kind of circular logic that goes on sometimes during upgrades they are able to operate independently if you're
a developer that also means that you can have a legacy development environment that's operating completely in a container that is separate from your
current development environment if for example you're making changes to some legacy code or a legacy application and
one last feature that I think is worth mentioning about wam it's a very feature-rich service we do have
something called configurable app events and the notion here is that when the application is being installed on the
workspaces end-users instance there may be activities that you need to execute
as part of the operation and installation of the package so for example you may need to create a local
user account for that application or maybe you've installed the productivity suite and you need to get a license key
from a key management server those things can be scripted as part of the package install using the configurable

private gateway and they don't have an Internet gateway the only mechanism by which they are able to commute with
